moves.5. c3 Nxe4 6. d4 exd4 7. cxd4 d5 8. dxc5: This sequence leaves me a Pawn up.
moves.9. Qe1 f5 10. Nc3 O-O 11. Bf4 Rf7 12. Rd: Both sides complete their development, and now the middle game begins.
moves.13. Nd4 Nxd4 14. Rxd4 Be6: I gladly swap off a pair of Knights.
moves.16. Be3 Rd8: I was anticipating 16 QxP evening up the material.
moves.19. Rfd1 Rd7xd4 20. Bxd4 Qf7: ...I swap off a pair of Rooks.
moves.21. Re1 Bd5: Now both my advanced Pawns are supported
moves.22. h3 b6 23. cxb6 cxb6: I undouble my Q side Pawns with this exchange.
moves.26. b3 b5: Guarding a Pawn with a Pawn is the simplest policy.
moves.27. bxc4 bxc4: Now I have a passed QBP.
moves.30. h4 Kf7: All but one of my pieces and Pawns are on white squares, rendering White's Bishop almost useless.
moves.31. f3 exf3 32. gxf3 Qb5: I feel my King is more safe now, so risk some attacking maneuvers.
moves.34. Qxb2 Rxb2+: Now we're in an OCB endgame.
moves.36. Kg3 Rxg2+: Swapping the Rooks and reducing White's winning chances to a value so close to zero that God herself couldn't tell the difference.
moves.37. Kxg2 Bxa2: Pure OCB endings are notoriously drawish, but now with TWO passed pawns I may have a chance at a win.
moves.43. Ke3 Kf5: I intend to threaten the K-side.
moves.48. Kh3 Ke4: ...but now I can switch to the Q-side.
moves.49. Kg3 Kd3: I intend to support my passed P's with my K.
moves.51. Ke1 Kc3: Now back to what I should be doing.
moves.52. Kf2 Kb3: Now I can advance my RP.
